title: Cocktail Guide and Notes
introduction: Welcome to the ultimate cocktail guide. Here you'll find categories of cocktails, how to create your own, and tips on adding to your bar.

sections.subtitle: Cocktail Categories
sections.body: Cocktail categories help organize drinks by their style and is often categorized by their ingredients. Below you can find the main categories and what defines them.

subsections.headline: Sours
subsections.description: Sours are classic cocktails that balance a base spirit with citrus juice and a sweetener, often shaken and served over ice. THe juice is usually lemon or lime, but can also be grapefruit juice (and sometimes orange juice). Examples of sours include: Whiskey sour, Cosmopolitan, Clover Club, Sidecar and The Last Word.

subsections.headline: Highballs and Fizzes
subsections.description: Highballs are mixed drinks consisting of a base spirit and a larger proportion of a non-alcoholic mixer, served over ice in a tall glass. Examples of Highballs include: Whiskey Highball and Pimm's Cup. More complex Highballs have added juice, liqueurs, or other ingredients. A Highball with the addition of lemon juice and sugar is called a Collins (Such as a Tom Collins). A fizz is in the style of a complex Highball but with the ingredients (excluding the mixer) shaken first. Examples include: Gin Fizz and Ramoz Fizz.

subsections.headline: Spirit-Forwards
subsections.description: Spirit-forward cocktails emphasize the base spirit with minimal mixers, often stirred and served neat or on the rocks. They are usually composed of a base spirit, a modifier (vermouth or similar) and bitters or a small amount of syrup or liqueur. Examples include: Martini, Manhattan, Negroni and El Presidente

subsections.headline: Mocktails
subsections.description: Mocktails are non-alcoholic beverages designed to mimic the complexity and flavor of traditional cocktails. If no alcohol is in the ingredients the cocktail belongs to this category.

subsections.headline: Tiki Cocktails
subsections.description: Tiki cocktails are tropical, often rum-based drinks with exotic fruit juices and elaborate garnishes. They usually consists of base spirits (1 spirit or a combination of different spirits), fruit juices and syrups and/or liqueurs, often deployed in various combinations. These cocktails are usually served over crushed ice. Examples inlcude: Zombie, Planter's Punch and Singapore Sling.

subsections.headline: Duos and Trios
subsections.description: Duos and Trios are simple combinations of two or three ingredients. This category of cocktails is similar to Spirit-Forwards when looking a Duos but with one key difference in the modifier. Duos consist of a base spirit and modifier (a liqueur or dash of bitters). Examples include: Stinger and Revolver. To create a trio a cream or cream liqueur is added. Trios are often found in dessert style cocktails. Examples include: Alexender (and its variations) and White Russian.

subsections.headline: Champagne Cocktails
subsections.description: Champagne cocktails incorporate sparkling wine with other ingredients and as such, cocktails in this category is quite varied. A champagne cocktail can be created by taking a Sour or Spirit-Forward cocktail and adding sparkling wine to it. Examples include: Champagne Cocktail, French 75 and Morning Glory Royale.

subsections.headline: Juleps and Smashes
subsections.description: Juleps and smashes are refreshing cocktails typically featuring muddled herbs, citrus, and a base spirit, served over crushed or cracked ice. Examples include: Mint julep, Whiskey Smash and Gin Basil Smash.

subsections.headline: Others
subsections.description: This category includes cocktails that don't fit neatly into the other classifications.
